[Music]
hi and welcome you listening to the x22
report my name is Dave and this is
episode 1590 a.n today's date is June
12th 2018 and the title of the episode
is the u.s. is one step closer to
bankruptcy let's get into the economic
collapse financial news now we
understand that the UK had a brexit vote
and the people wanted to basically
detach themselves from the EU and the
central bankers well they don't want
this to happen and they've been fighting
as hard as they possibly can the elite
the central bank's they don't want this
to happen and it looks like the UK prime
minister Theresa May might have won a
watered down vote that leaves her
cabinet in control the brexit
negotiations for now but in order to
avert mutiny she had to accept a
considerable concession now the UK
government wins by 324 vs. 298 in the
key brexit amendment now government will
use 5a and 5b but not 5c of the Greve
amendment as basis for a discussion on
meaningful vote the Greve amendment is a
slightly watered down version of the
original meaningful vote amendment the
House of Commons will be able to direct
brexit negotiations if there's no deal
by the end of November and lor mayor
lawmakers will have a veto on how it
goes from there the government has made
big concessions towards the Tory rebels
lobbying for a softer brexit this puts a
huge amount of pressure on Mays cabinet
to sort itself out and conclude a deal
with the October you summit now looking
like a Big Crunch date brexit returns to
Parliament it is likely to adopt a
softer approach and again the central
bankers the elite they're pushing back
they don't want this to happen and
they're trying to stop it at every turn
and we'll have to see how this whole
thing plays out and we can see that this
has been a difficult road and the people
still
want the brexit we know that the elite
the central bankers they told us how
this was going to fail they told us how
the economy was going to implode they
told us so many different things if this
went through and it didn't go through
and we saw nothing of what they said and
now they're saying well if the brexit
actually happens we're gonna see
shortages we're gonna see this we're
gonna see that again this has nothing to
do with the brexit this has to do with
the economy imploding and eventually
what's going to happen is the economy
will implode and if this goes through
guess what other countries are gonna
look at this and say we don't want to be
part of this either actually Italy is
looking at this right now they're
already taken the approach that maybe we
should be separate and apart from the EU
so it's already starting to spread and
we're gonna see other countries step up
and say the same exact thing here in the
United States we're starting to see
inflation consumer prices are surging
and let me just say this we've been
seeing inflation basically the central
banks the Fed have been pushing
inflation out into housing into the
student loan market into other countries
into health insurance health coverage
into many other things the stock market
so we don't see it on a everyday usage
of food supplies and things that we need
every day but we do see it we see we do
see prices increasing on many of these
things and for the 32nd consecutive
month the Consensus Estimate on the
street was 0.2 percent increase month on
month and expectations were met pushing
the headline CPI to 2.8 percent
year-on-year the highest since December
of 2011 the core CPI also rose to 2.1
percent this is the highest into 2017 of
January the indexes for new vehicles
education and communication tobacco
increased in May the index for all items
less food and energy rose by 2.2 percent
over the last 12 months after increasing
2.1 percent in the 12 months ending
March and April we also see the medical
care in
Dex rose by 2.4% shelter index rose by
3.5% over the last 12 months real wage
growth is slumping so as real wage
growth is slumping we're seeing
inflation in all these different areas
so this tells us it's going to be get
it's going to become more and more
difficult as we move forward and we're
gonna see a lot more inflation because
everything's starting to break down I
mean and we're seeing it across the
board here we're seeing it in every
economic sector we see it in the
automobile sector now auto lenders there
are they are becoming very very nervous
because they went to those people who
had good credit those people have subpar
credit those people have subprime credit
and they're running out of people to
lend money to and what they're doing
right now is they're taking anyone and
to get anyone in there extending the
loan terms they're reducing their
standards they're doing whatever they
possibly can to push sales because right
now the automobile industry is hurting
and what we're seeing right now is that
delinquencies they are rising because
what are they doing they're giving loans
to those people who really can't afford
it who can't make payments and they're
trying to bring these people in any way
they possibly can but eventually what
happens is they are delinquent on the
loans and many times they default now in
the first quarter the average loan term
for a new car exceeded 69 months the
second consecutive quarter it had ever
been above that level according to
Experian also in the first quarter new
car loans originated with repayment
periods of between 73 and 84 months
represented more than a third of total
new car loans up from 7% of loans in
late 2009 and what we're seeing here is
they're trying to do whatever they can
to lend money because that's the
business they're in and they need car
sales and they can see that it's
becoming more and more difficult
and basically eventually what's going to
happen you're just gonna run out of
people because what's going to happen
with all these people taking these loans
we're gonna see delinquencies rise we're
gonna see default rise and we're gonna
be heading into a major major problem
and what is that major problem well it's
going to be a bankrupt country
I mean we're heading in that direction
we're one step closer I mean listen to
what has come out from the Treasury now
according to the latest monthly Treasury
statement in May the u.s. collected 217
billion in receipts consisting of 93
billion in individual income tax a
hundred three billion in social security
and payroll tax three billion in
corporate tax 18 billion in other taxes
and duties a drop of nine point seven
percent from the 240 billion collected
last March and a clear reversal from the
recent increasing trend even as the
federal spending surged rising ten point
seven percent from three hundred and
twenty eight billion last March to three
hundred and sixty three billion last
month where was the money spent well it
was spent on Social Security eighty
three billion defense 56 billion
Medicare fifty three billion interest on
the debt thirty two billion and other a
hundred and forty-one billion the surge
in spending led to a may budget deficit
of a hundred and forty six billion above
the consensus estimate of a hundred and
forty four billion a swing from a
surplus of two hundred and fourteen
billion in April and far larger than the
deficit of eighty eighty eight billion
recorded in May of 2017 this was the
biggest March budget deficit since the
financial crisis meanwhile as rates blow
out the US debt is expected to keep
rising and somehow hit 30 trillion by
2028 so what do we see happening here
well the u.s. is continually spending
tax receipts are dropping and
this is a recipe for disaster we are one
step closer to bankruptcy this is the
whole point of this they're going to
continue this why because they need to
crash the current system who are they
Trump and the Patriots because we are
not in a people system I said this over
and over and over we are in a central
banking system we can't repair a central
banking system it doesn't work that way
the central banking system is designed
to fail because they keep loaning the
government money and it's attached with
interest there's not enough to pay this
back and with the people losing jobs
left and right and getting lower paying
jobs guess what you don't have the tax
receipts coming in we're going to see
this trend continue why do you think the
United States enacted the FATCA Gatka
laws where they can go across the globe
and find whatever funds they can
possibly find and bring them back here
and tax those people who are working
outside the United States because they
needed a way to bring in more tax
receipts that was the whole purpose the
whole system is designed to fail and the
only way to get out of this is to crash
it and to blame it on the central bank's
and say you know something we are not
going to restart this we don't need the
central bank's look what you've done to
Argentina look what you've done to
Greece look what you've done
to Cyprus look what you've done to Spain
Italy and the rest of the countries look
what you've done here you've put every
single country into debt and these
countries are barely making ends meet
and they continually push austerity on
the people that's what the central bank
does and then they robbed these
countries of their assets so what's
wrong with the economy well Charles Hugh
Smith lays it out for us
one the financialization of the economy
which transforms services credit risk
and labor into commodities that could be
traded globally financialization
generates enormous ly asymmetric returns
those with access to
low-cost credit global markets and
expertise in finance collect the lion's
share of gains in income and wealth
number two
the technological transformation of the
economy which has placed a substantial
scarcity premium on specific tech
managerial communication skills and
devalued ordinary labour and capital
as a result the majority of gains and
wealth and income flow to those with the
scarce skills and forms of capital
leaving little for the ordinary labour
and capital
number three globalization which
transformed the developing world into
the environmental dumping ground of the
wealthy nations and enabled the owners
of capital to offshore waste and labour
number four the destruction the
destructive consequences of growth at
any cost are piling up growth is the one
constant of all existing political
economic systems and none of the current
modes of production which is organized
production consumption the economy and
society recognize that growth is not
sustainable number five the dominance of
debt funded speculation as the means of
getting ahead as opposed to producing
products and services of intrinsic value
that serve the core needs of communities
number six the economy's gains in income
and wealth are concentrated in the very
top of wealth power pyramid the top five
percent entrepreneurs professionals
technocrats and within this class most
of these gains go to the top one-tenth
of a percent the existing owners of
wealth and financier speculators with
access to cheap credit these individuals
make out they understand they have the
insider information they have cheap
credit and they're the ones who become
very very wealthy and we see this in the
housing market the gains in housing are
concentrated in specific markets outside
these hot markets gains are modest think
about Case Shiller when they look at the
20 different cities where they see the
bubbles
going up and hedge funds investment
companies come in they buy all these
homes they're told to hold on to them
they use cheap credit and basically they
drive the prices up banks say banks are
told not to foreclose on houses keep
them off the market to drive prices up
asset bubbles eventually pop leaving
those still owning the assets with
losses the risks are thus intrinsic and
high the average investor gambler lacks
the experience needed to recognize the
bubble has stopped expanding and exit
the market before the other speculators
rush for the exits this is what we've
seen in the past actually this is what
we're seeing right now all of these
wealthy individuals that have pumped
these bubbles up
they are exiting and those who think
that these bubbles are going to continue
they're coming into the market this is
why you see speculators in the real
estate market this is why you see more
retailers in the stock market and
they're just rushing in and they're
going to take the fall number 7 the
devaluation of ordinary labor and
capital means the bottom 60% of the
economy that lacks the requisite skills
with scarcity premium in the emerging
economy have lost easy access to the
ladder of social mobility number 8 the
concentration of wealth and power in the
hands of the self-serving few corrupts
the economy and democracy the US economy
is dominated by insider and elite
rackets skins scams cartels quasi
monopolies all of which corrupt the
economy by creating perverse 'iv
incentives for exploitation and gaming
the system to benefit the few at the
expense of the many this corruption in
surface of maximizing private personal
gains at the expense of the system
itself also corrupts the mechanisms of
governance which are now little more
than cloaking devices that protect
insiders and elites from scrutiny and
consequences the 20% above the bottom
60% may appear to have some access to
social economic mobility but this is
largely an artifact of the bubble
economy since 2009
once the bubble deflate the
illusion of social mobility for the
middle class between the bottom 60% and
the upper 20% completely vanishes and
how is all this created it is created by
the central bank the central bank that
creates the currency out of thin air
that loans it to the government that
pays off those on Wall Street gives them
easy credit gives them insider
information pays off certain government
officials and also these government
officials are paid off by other interest
groups other countries it corrupts the
system completely and we end up with the
very wealthy and the poor and the middle
class
well they don't exist at all so what
we're seeing we're seeing a complete and
utter breakdown of the entire economic
system this is what happens in a central
bank economy and if you look back in
time and you look at the UK you look at
Spain and you look at the rest
throughout history you can see it's the
same exact pattern over and over where
the people are pushed to the edge and
eventually the people can't take it
anymore and they fight back this is why
we see revolutions this is why we see
Kings be having their heads cut off this
is why we see all of this because they
drive the people into a no-win situation
and the people at this point say you
know something well we have nothing we
have nothing to lose it's time to change
everything that is what we are seeing
today so the people are going to push
the system and push it hard until it
doesn't exist anymore and then we're
going to enter a transition this is what
we're seeing right now and we're going
to enter this transition and hopefully
the people take control and make it a
people system not a central bank system
so no matter what we're going through a
transition and I like I said before
whoever has the narrative is going to
win listen everyone thanks a lot for
listening be well be safe and especially
be prepared thanks a lot
